content.description: Good short route on good stone. The crux is getting past the second bolt.
content.protection: Four clips and a optional medium cam. Lower from a two bolt anchor.
content.location: Just right of Twisted Feet #23 in the Jackson guide.

content.description:
Begin in a nice dihedral with decent pro to get you to the first ledge. Step right and head straight up a broken crack system to the anchors on top of the climb just left of Esmerelda.  

  I took the "name" of this in the Foley guide to mean it was 5.8, but would call it significantly easier than that. I thought 5.6, but Hanna following me suggested 5.7, so there you have it.
content.protection: A single rack of cams to #4 will do you fine. I placed a .75, .5, 2 and 4. But, there are plenty of options and I only took the #4 because I had it and there was an obvious placement for it. Solid gear and plenty of it on the whole route.
content.location: The trad line two climbs left of Esmerelda that is climb #22 in the Foley Guide.

content.description: Mindtwisting stemming up an interesting right-facing dihedral with fun moves the whole way.  Sustained in its technical difficulty. Opinions may vary on where the crux is: at the 2nd bolt, or maybe committing moves at the top?  More of a mental puzzle than anything else, but quite fun.
content.protection: 5 bolts to a 2-bolt anchor.
content.location: Toward the right side of Dead Cholla, in the last section of cliff with climbs. (This is the leftmost climb is the bunch at the end).  This climb is 75' right of No Waiting (after Connected and Re-Connected).  It faintly follows a right-facing corner.  Having a guidebook with photos (Taos Rock, RC:NM) will help.

content.description:
Perhaps the best hard climb at Dead Cholla, this climb goes up an aesthetic prow.  Traverse in from the left to start, with some trickery involved to get over to the arete..  Hard, thin, reachy moves comprise the crux.  Near the top, I wound up in the shallow corner to the left, rather than on the face.

 One guidebook gives it 11+, the other one 12-.
content.protection: 6 bolts to a 2-bolt anchor.  (Anchors are challenging to reach from above. Be really careful if trying to set a TR.)
content.location: Just left of Special Ed.

content.description: Ledgy climbing in a shallow dihedral leads to a fantastic left-hand flake before climbing through the small roof with a finger crack through it near the top. Very strenuous and committing moves through the roof crux.    Then, good climbing in another shallow dihedral to the anchors.
content.protection: Five bolts to a two bolt anchor. The first bolt is a bit high but the climbing to that point isn't hard.    I liked a small cam (.3 or .2 BD camalot) in the crack at the crux roof but this isn't required. Small nuts would be great too.    Like many of the anchors at Dead Cholla, there are no lowering chains on these anchors. We just left our draws on the bolts and grabbed them from the top on our way out.
content.location: Two routes left of the easiest route, Fun, at Dead Cholla. Look for the great, positive flake left of the bolt line about halfway up the wall.

climbs.name: Somebody Loaned Me a Bosch
climbs.fa: somebody who didn't have their own Bosch

content.description: Start as for Doc's Dangle, with a reachy move by the first bolt.  While Doc's Dangle soon goes left, following the natural line, 'Somebody...' continues straight up, past 2 very close bolts and strange pockets/sidepulls/tiny crimps.  The only problem is that it is so close to the route to its left that it is much easier to clip the bolts and move through the crux using holds shared with that route... so you might as well just climb 'Docs Dangle' instead and spare yourself the dilemma of having to concern yourself with what is "on" and what's "off".  or maybe I was just missing something.
content.protection: 4 bolts to a 2-bolt anchor.
content.location: This climb shares the same start as Doc's Dangle, and is in fact a more contrived variation of the same route.

content.description: Hard move off the starting ledge. Crux is getting past the second bolt. Fun crack climbing leads to the anchor.
content.protection:
Two clips and small to medium pieces for the crack.  

  Lower from a two bolt anchor.
content.location: Start right of # 21 in the Jackson guide. Two obvious pockets and two bolts marked the start.

content.description: Surely one of the best and hardest all trad pitches at the crag and perhaps one of the hardest on Taos basalt (at published areas, anyway).  Beautiful thin fingers/tips crack between Blind Faith and Lava Flows.  Tricky and sustained for a ways, it looks to have decent pro with small cams (though I didn't lead it).  Rated 11+ in one book, 12- in the other; I'll put it at 12a as it felt harder than the 11d's I did.  Smaller fingers are going to help on this one.The anchor doesn't have chains and is a bit below the lip.  Be very careful trying to grab these from the top or trying to rig this for a TR (I slung the pillar above to access the bolts).
content.protection: Rack up to a 0.5 camalot, heavy on 0.2 and 0.3-sizes. 2-bolt anchor (no chains).
content.location: Obvious crack between Blind Faith and Lava Flows

content.description:
Reach up to a left leaning finger crack, place a cam, and lieback a burly move (crux) to a decent ledge.  Find gear here, and move up and right on face moves to the first bolt.  Sustained 5.9 face climbing follows the open book above, passing a 2nd bolt, then moving into cracks that progressively widen to small hands size as the difficuly eases.  Watch for loose pebbles just below the topout. 

  Another quality Dead Cholla crack, maybe just a little bit harder than Jam Time.
content.protection: 2 bolts + gear (1 set nuts, cams to 1.5").  This climb has anchors to the right of the topout that are hard to reach when leading up to them; alternatively, one can reach left to the Lava Flows anchor.
content.location: This climb is in the shallow dihedral/crack system just to the right of Lava Flows (which follows the first obvious bolted arete).

content.description: Good short route on great rock.
content.protection: A couple of medium cams for the start. Four clips, then lower from a two bolt anchor.
content.location: Start just left of "Either Or" (#26 in the Jackson guide).

content.description: Found in the Falcon Guide but not the Sharp End. Jam crack to a two bolt anchor.
content.protection: Medium Cams.
content.location: Dihedral right of Games, left of Corrido Del Norte.

content.description: The crux is a very thin slab move with horrible feet. Cool moves past the crux and fun finger crack to reach the anchors.
content.protection:
Four clips plus thin finger size gear.  

  Two bolt anchor.
content.location: Start just right of "Back to the Creek". Clip a bolt, make a hard dyno to a good edge, clip the second bolt and make a hard slab move (crux) to gain a good stance. Make a hard move past the third bolt and then gain the finger crack. Cruise to the anchors.

content.description:
The crux is the overhanging bouldery start. Great climbing and thin finger jamming to reach the anchor.  

  One of the best routes on the crag.
content.protection: Small cams and quickdraws.
content.location: The right most bolted route on the crag.

content.description:
Another quality face and arête route on great rock involving some arête slapping and crimpy edging.  Start at the undercut rock with a bush in the crack on the left. Pull up over the undercut on positive flake edges and face climbing past a horizontal crack for your first piece. More face climbing with thin moves between nice horizontal cracks takes you past a couple of bolts before getting into the crux on the blunt arête.  

  Take time to ponder your route up higher and choose whether to stay just left of the arête, on the arête or just right of the arête or all three.
content.protection: A small cam (.4 or .5 BD camalot) in the nice horizontal crack at about 12 feet and then 5 bolts to a two bolt anchor. Like many of the anchors at Dead Cholla, there are no lowering chains on these anchors. We just left our draws on the anchors and grabbed them from the top on our way out.
content.location: This route is closer to the left end of the wall. It's easily identified as the beautiful, dark rock arête.   See the route topo photo for Open Season for location.

content.description:
Jam your way up a finger crack to a hand crack through a crux section about 10' up, to more featured/broken crack climbing above and a 2-bolt anchor.   

  Good pro all the way.  5.10 grade is soft compared to 5.10 cracks at White Rock.
content.protection: 1 set cams to a 2-bolt anchor.
content.location: Hike the approach to Dead Cholla.  Stop at the first bolted climb you see (Bob..it). Jam Time is the hand crack to its left.

content.description: Sweet bolted overhanging crack/seam on a nice panel.  Above the last bolt, the climb exits to very easy blocky terrain for 15' and a 2-bolt anchor to the left.  Quite similar in style and difficulty to Special Ed.
content.protection: 4 or 5 bolts to a 2-bolt anchor (no chains, grab them from the top).
content.location: Obvious overhanging crack on a panel around the corner right of the Jam Time/Lava Flows staging area

content.description: Arete and thin face climb on the arete just right of Fun.  Interesting moves and the ever-present question to step around the corner or to stay on the side you're on.
content.protection: 5 bolts to a 2-bolt anchor
content.location: This climb is midway across Dead Cholla Wall.  It's hard to describe without a guide with photos (RC:NM or Taos Rock).  If you find the climb Fun, which leads up to a big block and turns it on the right, Games is just to its right.

content.description: A straightforward line that is easier than it looks. Makes for a nice warmup for this area. Straightforward climbing with plenty of positive holds and only a couple tricky sections.
content.protection: 5 bolts, option of gear down low if the easy runout is not comfortable.
content.location: This is the bolted line just to the left of Esmerelda. It's between climb 22 in the Foley guide and Esmerelda. Goes straight up the dihedral after some blocky stuff down low.

content.description: The easiest route on the entire wall.  The crux is turing the lip.  A small cam will protect the upper section.  Could be climbed all on gear but the rope drag or long slings would make things tough.
content.protection: 2 Bolts, Small Cam, and Chain Anchors
content.location: Middle of the wall look for the 2 bolts in a dihedral that turns a lip with a nice flake for pro.

content.description: Tough start, great moves! Just barely hand jam a right slanting crack to a small crack above. Good gear all the way.
content.protection: Medium cams to very small, #1 and #0 Metolious.
content.location: Incorrectly labeled in the Falcon Guide this is an obvious right slanting hand crack that's right of the line on P.48

content.description: A quality arête route. Clip a very well-placed bolt just over the roof at the blocky start before going into the thin, technical crux of the route getting up to, and past, the second bolt.  Then enjoy fun face and arête climbing to the anchor.    The route steepens near the top but the holds are juggy making for some great position and moves.
content.protection: 5 bolts to a two-bolt anchor. Like many of the anchors at Dead Cholla, there are no lowering chains on these anchors. We just left our draws on the bolts and grabbed them from the top on our way out.  On this route, it's a bit of a stretch to grab the draws from the top but there is another set of bolts up on top so one could set a TR very easily.
content.location: This is the next to last bolted route on the far end of the wall, just left of the route Leave it to Bob which has gray hangers.    It's easily identifiable by the undercut, blocky start to the nice arête above.

content.description: A boulder problem off the ground and starting from the crack to the right allows one to reach a great incut ledge and mantle up to the first good rest ledge.  Next, move a little left of the arete, make a tricky move (crux) to reach the next good hold and clip the third bolt (avoid the temptation to reach over to 'Nice' crack to the left).  Continue from here on the right side of the arete using sweet pockets and positive ledges.   Fun moves, but a little contrived, as the more natural line, Nice, is within reach at the hard part.
content.protection: 4 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor.  The anchor stinks for lowering (just bolts, no links), so plan on leaving your draws and getting them when you walk out, or reach over to the 'Nice' anchors to the left.
content.location: This climb is toward the right side of the section of Dead Cholla with Twisted Feet.  This climb follows the arete/face to the right of Nice, and is the 1st bolted climb left of the prominent Esmerelda arete.

content.description: The crux is the overhanging thin hands section.
content.protection: Quickraws and a couple of medium size cams.
content.location: Start just left of Fun.

content.description: Face climb past a reachy move by the first bolt.  Follow the bolts angling to the left, onto the less-than vertical face past some good but slightly dirty holds.   Not bad for an all-bolted 5.10 at Dead Cholla.
content.protection: 3 bolts to a 2-bolt anchor.  The anchor has no chains or links for lowering/rappelling, so plan on picking your gear up from the top, or reach over to Somebody Loaned Me a Bosch anchors to get down.
content.location: This climb is in the rightmost section of cliff at Dead Cholla.  It lies immediately right of Waiting for the Sun and Twisted Feet.

content.description: The crux is stemming past the first two bolts.
content.protection: RP's, small to medium cams.
content.location: Start just left of Re-Connected.

content.description: This crack is a nice-looking line, but ends up being much tricky than expected at its thin crux and dirty up high.  I suspect there was at some point a bolt protecting the crux (says there is one on the route in the books), but it is not there, and is going to be scary to lead as is.  Unfortunately, above the crux, the crack gets wide, dirty, and has many scary-looking wedged blocks in it, though it is an easier section.
content.protection: not sure. standard rack includng thin gear? 2-bolt anchor with cold shuts
content.location: Corner right of Open Season, left of Hageemoto

content.description: A hard series of moves over a bulge.
content.protection: Quickdraws and a green Alien (at the start).
content.location: Start just right of the classic Jam Time.

content.description: Stem your way to the first bolt.  Some may want a cam to protect this, but most will be comfortable as it's less than 5.9 to this bolt.  Intriguing stemming leads up the bleached dihedral above to a 2-bolt anchor.
content.protection: 3 bolts to a 2-bolt anchor.  Some may want some small cams to get to the first bolt.
content.location: This climb is the 2nd bolted climb you come to at Dead Cholla.  It is a left-facing corner in the alcove area with Jam Time and Bob..it, and is just right of Bob..It.

content.description:
Start just right of Corrido del Norte (#19 in Jackson's Guide).  

  Scramble up loose low angle rock and clip a bolt in an inset corner. Jam the overhanging finger crack (gear) to a ledge. Continue straight up past three more bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.protection: Four clips plus finger size gear for the crack.

content.description: Lots of sun early as the crag faces East.  Plenty of shade later.  It can get a little chilly on nights in the winter.  Most of the routes have chains at the top which can be reached to set up top ropes.  Many fantastic lines are on this quality wall.  A great mix of splitters and sport climbs as well.  Almost all the routes are in the 10-12 range.
